subs.text: April 2022
subs.name: april2022

subs.text: April 6

@glogeex @Aviation_Intel Satellites are too far away to _reliably_ communicate with legacy ballistic missile submarines at (or below) periscope depth.

The closer the transmitter, the easier it is to communicate through jamming or interference (e.g. interference caused by post-nuclear blast ionization).
subs.rawText:
@glogeex @Aviation_Intel Satellites are too far away to _reliably_ communicate with legacy ballistic missile submarines at (or below) periscope depth.

The closer the transmitter, the easier it is to communicate through jamming or interference (e.g. interference caused by post-nuclear blast ionization).

subs.text:
@DaveD1973 @MarkHertling That word seems to be reserved for mostly longer-range missiles?

Honestly, the whole ‘hypersonic’ thing seems like a lot of hype. Objects that fast can easily be audibly triangulated; stand-off radar picket lines can communicate with distant defense systems at nearly lightspeed.
subs.rawText:
@DaveD1973 @MarkHertling That word seems to be reserved for mostly longer-range missiles?

Honestly, the whole ‘hypersonic’ thing seems like a lot of hype. Objects that fast can easily be audibly triangulated; stand-off radar picket lines can communicate with distant defense systems at nearly lightspeed.

subs.text: @LipkaPasha @TrentTelenko Size and shape appear to be distorted on the left and right edges of that photograph due to the lens used, so that ‘dune buggy’ probably is much narrower IRL.
subs.rawText: @LipkaPasha @TrentTelenko Size and shape appear to be distorted on the left and right edges of that photograph due to the lens used, so that ‘dune buggy’ probably is much narrower IRL.

subs.text:
@igorsushko Part of the point of the US releasing that intelligence was also to inform as many people as possible.

Advance notice of likely tactics allowed countermeasures to be put into place (e.g. disconnecting electrical transmission SCADA systems from networks, to prevent cyber attacks)
subs.rawText:
@igorsushko Part of the point of the US releasing that intelligence was also to inform as many people as possible.

Advance notice of likely tactics allowed countermeasures to be put into place (e.g. disconnecting electrical transmission SCADA systems from networks, to prevent cyber attacks)

subs.text:
@igorsushko i.e. the intelligence releases were acting as a sort of “ghost of Christmas future”; describing one possible future that could occur. 

Recall that at least publicly, Ukraine was saying (until almost immediately before) that the Russians wouldn’t actually invade at all.

subs.text:
@Ed_Fryer @PhillipsPOBrien They’ll probably start converting some roads to multi-gauge (i.e. 3 rails) as needed. Then, the existing equipment can be continued to be used.

That’s what parts of Great Britain did when they changed gauges early on.

subs.text:
@Javier_F @BrianWhedon @Euan_MacDonald It sounds like the implication is that different sized ships are sometimes commanded by different ranks.

US Navy example:
 - Enlisted NCO commands motor launch
 - LT commanded WWII PT boat
 - CDR commands fast-attack submarine
 - CAPT commands cruiser

(generally)

subs.text: April 1

@TheRobinCommon1 @BeauTFC Uncertainty can increase the psychological pressure on an enemy as well.

Was it sabotage?

Was it NATO frogmen?

Was it divine retribution?

Was it rouge Russian pilots?

Did we deserve it somehow?

If these types of questions distract even one Russian soldier, that’s a win.
